https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/katherine-heigl-dieting-was-awful-2007116/	[{"@context": "https://schema.org", "@type": "Organization", "name": "Us Weekly", "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com", "parentOrganization": "McClatchy Media", "logo": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com/wp-content/themes/us-weekly/assets/img/usweekly-logo.png", "width": 200, "height": 180}, "address": {"@type": "PostalAddress", "streetAddress": "1601 Alhambra Blvd., Suite 100", "addresslocality": "Sacramento", "postalCode": "CA 95816"}, "sameAs": ["https://www.facebook.com/UsWeekly", "https://www.instagram.com/usweekly/?hl=en", "https://twitter.com/usweekly", "https://www.tiktok.com/@usweekly?lang=en", "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCVxZlxikHMY8LzspzinH1ww"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org", "@type": "NewsArticle", "@id": "https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/katherine-heigl-dieting-was-awful-2007116/#article", "mainEntityOfPage": "https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/katherine-heigl-dieting-was-awful-2007116/", "publisher": {"@id": "https://www.usmagazine.com/#organization"}, "headline": "Katherine Heigl: Dieting Was &#8220;Awful&#8221;\u009d", "datePublished": "2007-06-11T15:15:00-04:00", "dateModified": "2017-12-06T22:54:18-05:00", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Us Weekly Staff", "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com/author/us-weekly-staff/"}, "description": "Katherine Heigl speaks about a number of issues.", "articleBody": "Katherine Heigl, the most outspoken member of the Grey&apos;s Anatomy cast (well, after Isaiah Washington) sounds off on pregnancy, growing up Mormon and her weight-loss struggle in the July issue of Glamour.     In fact, she even reveals the secret to avoiding the pressure to stay thin in Hollywood: Throw out the scale! &quot;It makes you kind of crazy,&quot; she says.\r\nSee interview highlights below as Heigl, 28, who is set to marry her fiance, singer Josh Kelley, in October, gets candid about falling in love and where she sees herself in 10 years.\r\nOn what prompted her to publicly chastise Isaiah Washington:&#xA0;&quot;At the time, I was a girl whose best friend had been hurt. I was mad, I&apos;d had a glass or two of champagne, and an interviewer asked me about it. Later, when I watched it on the news, I thought, I&apos;m totally going to get in trouble for this. I knew I wasn&apos;t playing the political game, the network wants us to promote a healthy, happy environment, and I&apos;m usually all for that, but that particular incident really infuriated me, and I couldn&apos;t hold my tongue. I think it&apos;s really pathetic there&apos;s still so much bigotry in 2007, and I would speak out again if the situation arose.&quot;&#x9D;\r\nOn whether it felt weird pretending to be pregnant:&#xA0;&quot;No, because the prosthetic belly felt so fake. Plus, my character was this super-in-shape reporter, so I had to lose ten pounds for the role. When I do get pregnant, I highly doubt Ill be one of those women who don&apos;t look pregnant from behind, I&apos;ll be that chick who looks pregnant from her ankles up.&quot;\r\nOn whether it was hard to lose weight for the role:&#xA0;&quot;It was awful! I remember once reading an article about Jessica Alba,&#xA0;who is the most beautiful, most in-shape person alive and how committed she was to her regimen. And I thought, There is no way in hell that will ever be me. I can&apos;t only eat fish and vegetables or work out seven days a week. Then suddenly I was that person and I was shocked. But I could never maintain it. I like food too much!&#xA0;\r\nOn how she ignores the pressure in Hollywood to stay thin:&#xA0;&quot;When I see some of the people who are glorified in magazines these days, who are so thin it&apos;s bordering on sickness, I just feel exhausted. I would hate to think that young girls in high schools across America think that&apos;s what they&apos;re supposed to look like.&quot;&#xA0;\r\nOn who she thinks has a healthy body in Hollywood:&#xA0;&quot;Jennifer Aniston and Halle Berry are both in amazing shape. They look phenomenal but they don&apos;t look sick. Then there&apos;s Kate Winslet: She&apos;s confident, beautiful, talented and sexy and she owns it. Early in my career, I read an interview she gave about how the industry wanted her to lose weight; she basically gave them the finger and said no. I remember thinking, I can do that too. I don&apos;t have to look like one of these genetically superior people in order to work.&quot;&#xA0;\r\nOn when she knew Josh Kelley was The One:&#xA0;&quot;We definitely had chemistry at first sight. In the beginning, I was a little intimidated because I thought I was more into him than he was into me. But I was tired of playing games, tired of playing it cool, tired of trying to remain in control of my relationships. So I was honest about how I felt, he was honest right back, and within a month and a half I was completely in love with this guy.&quot;\r\nOn growing up Mormon:&#xA0;&quot;I am really supportive of the Mormon church and so profoundly grateful for the childhood I had. It&apos;s hard work to grow and change and be honest with yourself about your mistakes, and I think that the Mormons handle that beautifully. The faith I grew up with has influenced every decision I&apos;ve made in my life, well except for the bad ones. [laughs]\r\nOn coping with the death of her brother who died in a car accident when she was seven: &quot;I think about what our lives would be like now if he were still alive: what he&apos;d be doing, where he&apos;d be living, whether I&apos;d see him often, whether he&apos;d have kids. These are the things you think about when someone dies, all the potential that never was. It stays with you forever.&quot;&#xA0;\r\nOn where she sees herself in 10 years: &quot;I hope to have children and the sort of family traditions where we eat together every night. But my career is also super important to me. I don&apos;t think I could ever be a stay-at-home mom. So I&apos;ll have to find a way to combine the two in a healthy and productive way.&quot;", "isPartOf": {"@id": Clutching a bottle of Smart Water and wearing short workout shorts, she smiled for photographers.  \n\nIt was one of Simpson&apos;s first public outings since her split with Romo. (She also enjoyed a girls&apos; night out with pals last Saturday, writing on her Twitter page: &quot;Love my ladies!!!&quot;)  \n\nEarlier this year, Simpson underwent scrutiny for flaunting a fuller figure an an outdoor concert.  \nSee Jessica Simpson&apos;s signature style\nA source tells Usmagazine.com her relationship with Romo caused her to pack on a few extra pounds.  &quot;Tony was always threatening to break up with her, and it would send her into a panic,&quot; says the source. &quot;That&apos;s why she&apos;s gaining so much- it&apos;s emotional eating.&quot;\n\nNow Simpson wants to get back in shape, sources tell Us. She is set to shoot The Price of Beauty, a VH1 reality show that has her traveling the world to learn about body image. The show debuts in 2010.\nIn the meantime, Simpson&apos;s personal trainer, Harley Pasternak, is hosting a MSN Web series, Focus on Feeling Better, to offer health and wellness tips and tricks.", https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/report-at-least-five-jackson-docs-under-investigation-200967/	[{"@context": "https://schema.org", "@type": "Organization", "name": "Us Weekly", "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com", "parentOrganization": "McClatchy Media", "logo": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com/wp-content/themes/us-weekly/assets/img/usweekly-logo.png", "width": 200, "height": 180}, "address": {"@type": "PostalAddress", "streetAddress": "1601 Alhambra Blvd., Suite 100", "addresslocality": "Sacramento", "postalCode": "CA 95816"}, "sameAs": ["https://www.facebook.com/UsWeekly", "https://www.instagram.com/usweekly/?hl=en", "https://twitter.com/usweekly", "https://www.tiktok.com/@usweekly?lang=en", "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCVxZlxikHMY8LzspzinH1ww"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org", "@type": "NewsArticle", "@id": "https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/report-at-least-five-jackson-docs-under-investigation-200967/#article", "mainEntityOfPage": "https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/report-at-least-five-jackson-docs-under-investigation-200967/", "publisher": {"@id": "https://www.usmagazine.com/#organization"}, "headline": "Report: At Least Five Jackson Docs Under Investigation", "datePublished": "2009-07-06T12:04:13-04:00", "dateModified": "2017-12-06T22:56:30-05:00", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Us Weekly Staff", "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com/author/us-weekly-staff/"}, "description": "Police want to know who prescribed the singer the powerful sedative Diprivan", "articleBody": "At least five doctors who prescribed drugs to Michael Jackson are under investigation, the Los Angeles Times reports.\nAuthorities have removed drugs and other medical evidence from the rented Los Angeles mansion where Jackson suffered cardiac arrest in his bedroom June 25.\nSee how Michael Jackson&apos;s face has changed over the years\nPolice found &quot;numerous bottles&quot; of the powerful sedative Diprivan at the home, said a source, who spoke to the Times on the condition of anonymity because it is an ongoing investigation. The drug is supposed to be dispensed by a person trained to administer anesthesia and possible side effects include heart and breathing problems.\nAuthorities are trying to determine whether the medications were properly prescribed and whether they played any role in his death. The Times reports that names on some of the prescriptions were under Jackson pseudonyms. In some cases, according to the Times, the drugs had no prescription labels on them at all.\nLook back at Michael Jackson&apos;s life\nDr. Conrad Murray, the Texas cardiologist who was with Jackson when he died, met with Los Angeles police June 27, but his spokesman insists he &quot;is in no way a suspect and remains a witness to this tragedy.&quot;\nIt remains unknown whether prescription drugs played a role in Jackson&apos;s death. The Los Angeles County coroner&apos;s office is awaiting the results of toxicology testing before determining a cause of death. The results of a second autopsy haven&apos;t been released.  \nSee photos of Michael Jackson and his kids through the years\nBrian Oxman - who has served as the family&apos;s attorney for more than 20 years - previously told Usmagazine.com he suspects prescription drugs led to Jackson&apos;s death.  \nRevisit Michael Jackson&apos;s most unforgettable moments\n&quot;I only know that I warned them I live this fantastic life, full of all these magical things, and at the end of the day all I want to do is pick up my phone and share it with someone,&quot; she says. &quot;The other day I&apos;d sold a million records in the U.S. and I didn&apos;t have anyone to tell. It was actually a really lonely moment.&quot; But finding the right guy is &quot;difficult because I&apos;m so picky,&quot; she continues.\r\nCan you believe these couples dated?\r\nBeing famous has made it harder to find romance as well.\r\n&quot;If I go out to dinner with a guy, people automatically think we&apos;re dating,&quot; Perry says. &quot;And then when you do start dating, it becomes a race to the altar. And he can&apos;t be jealous because I&apos;m a very touchy-feely person,&quot; she says. &quot;And he&apos;d need to be able to tell me both yes and no. It also is the first time the actress, 44, had to shoot a nude scene.\n&quot;Sadly, my first and last nude scene got laughs, so I had to be very secure with that,&quot; she said Sunday at the film&apos;s press junket. &quot;It was all about choreography. I mean, literally when you read it on the page, you saw it, and then you realized, &apos;OK, there is no way to shoot this unless you are buck naked!&apos; Then I went, &apos;Go to the gym, cut out the carbs!&apos;&quot;  \nSee stars who have no problem showing a little skin\nThe scene -- which involves a naked run-in scene with costar Ryan Reynolds -- took three days to film and over a dozen takes.  &quot;I&apos;m glad it made people laugh,&quot; she said. &quot;Shooting it was odd. There are things stuck to areas that generally you don&apos;t have things [stuck to]. I mean, you have things covering [your body], but not stuck to it. And then they got unstuck, and oddly we didn&apos;t care because we were so tired.&quot;\nAdded Reynolds, &quot;Yeah, at that point, shame is gone completely. The weirdest part is calling your mom nude on set: &apos;Hey, just checking in!&apos;&quot;  \nSee photos of Ryan Reynolds and other stars sweating it out at the gym \nThe Proposal is Bullock&apos;s first romantic comedy since 2005&apos;s Miss Congeniality 2: Armed &amp; Fabulous.  &quot;I stopped doing them,&quot; she said. &quot;They are terrible, they are bad. They are not funny, so they shouldn&apos;t be a romantic comedy and most of the time they are not romantic. So they shouldn&apos;t be called a romantic comedy. They should be called that other kind of film.&quot;  \nSee then-and-now photos of your favorite romantic comedy stars\nShe said she refuses to call The Proposal a romantic comedy.  &quot;It reminds me of the films from like the &apos;30s and &apos;40s where there was a landscape and a story and drama was allowed to be in there,&quot; she said. &quot;You can&apos;t have good comedy without drama in it. And they don&apos;t generally write well for women in romantic comedies.&quot;\nSee stars who have no problem showing a little skin\n&quot;I love my comedy too much to bastardize it with bad romantic comedy,&quot; she went on. &quot;So I was like, &apos;I&apos;m going to find another way to work and do it in a way that I love.&apos; So I&apos;m not calling this a romantic comedy.&quot;", https://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/bruno-draws-mixed-reviews-from-critics-2009107/	[{"@context": "https://schema.org", "@type": "Organization", "name": "Us Weekly", "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com", "parentOrganization": "McClatchy Media", "logo": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com/wp-content/themes/us-weekly/assets/img/usweekly-logo.png", "width": 200, "height": 180}, "address": {"@type": "PostalAddress", "streetAddress": "1601 Alhambra Blvd., Suite 100", "addresslocality": "Sacramento", "postalCode": "CA 95816"}, "sameAs": ["https://www.facebook.com/UsWeekly", "https://www.instagram.com/usweekly/?hl=en", "https://twitter.com/usweekly", "https://www.tiktok.com/@usweekly?lang=en", "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCVxZlxikHMY8LzspzinH1ww"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org", "@type": "NewsArticle", "@id": "https://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/bruno-draws-mixed-reviews-from-critics-2009107/#article", "mainEntityOfPage": "https://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/bruno-draws-mixed-reviews-from-critics-2009107/", "publisher": {"@id": "https://www.usmagazine.com/#organization"}, "headline": "Bruno Draws Mixed Reviews From Critics", "datePublished": "2009-07-10T17:23:15-04:00", "dateModified": "2017-12-06T22:56:40-05:00", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Us Weekly Staff", "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com/author/us-weekly-staff/"}, "description": "Sacha Baron Cohen's controversial comedy (out today) is called \"a lazy piece of work\" and \"brilliant\"", "articleBody": "Sacha Baron Cohen&apos;s Bruno (in theaters today) has received mixed reactions from critics.\r\nThe controversial comedy -- which features Cohen as a flamboyant Austrian fashion designer -- has been deemed everything from &quot;mean-spirited&quot; to &quot;brilliant.&quot;\r\nSee photos of stars on set.\r\n&quot;Assuming outlandish guises, gulling the gullible and piling on the transgressive jokes, including plenty of gay-panic-inducing antics, is Sacha Baron Cohen&apos;s shtick,&quot; writes James Verniere in the Boston Herald. &quot;Well, the shtick is getting a bit short, already.\r\n&quot;The result, directed once again by Larry Charles and co-scripted by Cohen, is like an Austin Powers movie without the characters, plot or story line. That&apos;ll be 10 bucks, sucker,&quot; continues the Herald critic.\r\nAdds CNN: &quot;Perhaps inspired by another Cohen creation, Ali G, he sets out to make a celebrity interview show -- but sadly, the only dupes ignorant enough to participate are American Idol judges and presidential candidates [Ron Paul is  inadvertently cast in a sex tape].&quot;\r\nThe New York Times calls Cohen a &quot;brilliant slapstick artist and a master of voices -- Bruno&apos;s mock-German and scrambled American idioms are in some ways even more crazily spot-on than Borat&apos;s gibberish.&quot;\r\nSee photos of famous funny faces.\r\nBut the paper isn&apos;t won over by the movie.\r\n&quot;In spite of Mr. Baron Cohen&apos;s...high-level skills and keen low-comic instincts, Bruno is a lazy piece of work that panders more than it provokes,&quot; writes critic A.O. Scott.\r\nThe The Hollywood Reporter calls Cohen&apos;s ambushes &quot;too often...mean-spirited.\r\n&quot;We sense, as we never did with Borat, the comic behind the character. Especially when his accent keeps changing -- from an unconvincing Austrian to his own British and even to a whisper of Borat himself,&quot; it writes.\r\nBut Entertainment Weekly grades the film &quot;A-&quot; and says it&apos;s &quot;funnier than Borat.&quot;\r\n&quot;The entire film is in seriously questionable taste, and there will, of course, be debates about what&apos;s staged and what&apos;s not. Those looking for purity in satire should stay away. Yet there&apos;s a vision at work in Bruno -- the movie is a toxic dart aimed at the spangly new heart of American hypocrisy: our fake-tolerant, fake-charitable, fake-liberated-yet-still madly-closeted fame culture. Bruno ends on a note of scandalously funny out-and-proud triumph.&quot;  \r\nVariety bets the flick will open to high box office figures, calling it &quot;undeniably funny, outrageous and boundary-pushing.&quot;\r\nSee photos of today&apos;s top news stories.\r\nBut the controversial content will turn off some moviegoers, the magazine points out.\r\n&quot;There is also a pronounced nasty streak to the innumerable provocations staged by the title character that curdles the laughs and wears out the ... Austrian fashionista&apos;s welcome within the picture&apos;s brief 82-minute running time,&quot; Variety wrote.\r\nTell Us: Will you see Bruno this weekend?", "isPartOf": {"@id": at Cedars-Sinai, Dennis Quaid&#8217;s Twins Given Accidental Overdose, Fighting for Their Lives", "datePublished": "2007-11-20T19:08:00-05:00", "dateModified": "2017-12-06T22:54:20-05:00", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Us Weekly Staff", "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com/author/us-weekly-staff/"}, "description": "His rep tells Us he and his wife \"appreciate everyone's thoughts and prayers\"", "articleBody": "Dennis Quaid&apos;s newborn twins are in stable condition after being given an accidental drug overdose at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles.\r\n&quot;This was a preventable error, involving a failure to follow our standard policies and procedures,&quot; Dr. Michael L. Langberg, the Chief Medical Officer of Cedars-Sinai said in a statement to Usmagazine.com &quot;I want to extend my deepest apologies to the families who were affected by this situation,&quot; Langberg said.\r\nIn a statement to Us, Quaid&apos;s rep said: &quot;Dennis and [his wife] Kimberly appreciate everyone&apos;s thoughts and prayers and hope they can maintain their privacy at this difficult time.&quot;\r\nThomas Boone and Zoe Grace -- whom Quaid and his wife welcomed via a surrogate on November 8 -- were given a 10,000 units of Heparin, an anti-coagulant used to flush out IV lines and prevent blood clots this past Sunday and began to &quot;bleed out,&quot; TMZ.com first reported Tuesday. (Babies typically get 10 units.)\r\n&quot;They are doing well, much better,&quot; the twins&apos; grandmother, Delia Buffington, 62, told the New York Daily News. &quot;I certainly am thankful for that.&quot;\r\nThe newborns, who are in the hospital&apos;s neo-natal intensive care unit, are being given protamine sulfate, which reverses the effects of Heparin.  Doctors are continuing to closely monitor the three patients who were affected by the drug mix up, according to Langberg.\r\n&quot;We are conducting a comprehensive investigation, cooperating fully with the California Department of Public Health and will take all necessary steps to ensure that this never happens again,&quot; the Chief Medical Officer said.", "isPartOf": {"@id": Later, she&apos;ll dine on chicken and fruit.\r\nSee what else pregnant stars crave\r\n&quot;Watermelon is my cure for an upset stomach,&quot; she says. &quot;I get cranky when Hank steals mine!&quot;\r\nBut she still hits the gym with a take-it-easy regimen that involves lifting 8-pound weights while sitting on an exercise ball. (&quot;I&apos;m used to doing reps with 15 pounds, but I definitely don&apos;t want to do that now,&quot; she says.)&#xA0;\r\nThe former Girls Next Door star also walks on a treadmill and hikes.&#xA0;\r\n&quot;I&apos;m going to start taking yoga,&quot; she says.\r\nSee what an expert has to say about star baby names\r\nFive-months-pregnant Kourtney Kardashian, 30, hasn&apos;t been as focused on physical fitness.\r\n&quot;I haven&apos;t been going to the gym as much,&quot; says the former running enthusiast, who has added 13 pounds to her 102-pound frame. Kardashian, who is 5-foot-1, has been taking 4-mile hikes with her mom, Kris, and sisters Khloe and Kendall in their Hidden Hills, Calif. neighborhood.\r\nBut even though she&apos;s relaxed her workout routine, she&apos;s not loading up on junk food.\r\nFind out who else is pregnant this season\r\nBeau Scott Disick jokes, &apos;Get Twinkies and doughnuts!&apos; But I want to eat healthy,&quot; she explains. Instead, she opts for Oatmeal, fruit or Raisin Bran for breakfast and a Caprese sandwich on wheat ciabatta for lunch.&#xA0;\r\nBut when she&apos;s dining out, she&apos;s not afraid to splurge: &quot;I her deputy press secretary, Semonti Mustaphi, said Thursday.  \nSee photos of Michelle Obama&apos;s European style!\nObama and Bruni-Sarkozy -- who have met twice in recent months -- are both widely known as two of the most fashionable political wives. PETA has pushed Bruni-Sarkozy -- who was photographed wearing what appeared to be fur -- in particular to donate her coats to the homeless.\nSee photos of the Obama&apos;s first 100 days in Washington.\n&quot;I do not wear, buy or own fur or animal skin other than leather or skin of animals raised for feeding purposes,&quot; she said in a letter to PETA. &quot;I am not a vegetarian, and I don&apos;t find it illogical to wear skins of animals whose meat is also eaten. I would gladly consider giving away sable, fox and other fur coats -- if I owned any.&quot;\nUnlike Bruni-Sarkozy, Obama wasn&apos;t targeted by PETA.  &quot;We&apos;ve never written to Michelle Obama about this issue because we have always known her to be fur-free,&quot; Amanda Schinke, media campaigns coordinator for PETA, said.\nSee photos the Obama&apos;s pet dog, Bo!\nStill, less than a week after a sightseeing trip to France with her family, Obama followed suit with the former French supermodel.\n&quot;For Michelle Obama, respecting animals is obviously part of the social progress that she and her husband are working so hard to promote,&quot; PETA Senior Vice President Dan Mathews said. &quot;By officially rejecting fur, these two style icons will make people everywhere see fur for Judy and Larry Vardon, weighed down by a mortgage payment that has almost doubled since the makeover, worries the house could face foreclosure.\r\nFind our more about the curse of reality TV.\r\nWhen host Ty Pennington arrived at the Vardon&apos;s home with the Extreme Home Makeover crew four years ago, he promised to give them a home that would help them better accommodate their blind, autistic son. The episode, which aired Nov. 6, 2004, set a ratings record when millions of viewers tuned in to see the tranformation of the 980 square-foot home in Oak Park, Michigan.  In addition to mortgage payments, the couple also owes $20,000 for autism treatment -- which isn&apos;t covered by their medical insurance -- for their 16-year-old son, Lance. Larry Vardon also worries that he&apos;ll keep his job at Chrysler LLC&apos;s Sterling Heights stamping plant, as the company -- along with other Detroit automakers -- is on the brink of bankruptcy.   &quot;I&apos;m afraid I&apos;m going to lose my house now,&quot; Judy Vardon, using sign language through an interpreter, told The Macomb Daily of Mount Clemens. &quot;This house really belongs to Lance. This is his environment. He can&apos;t speak out for himself, and I hope we can save this house.&quot;  After the makeover, which included installing flat-screen monitors for Lance, the couple refinanced the mortgage. Their monthly payments went from $1,200 to $2,300.\r\nSee photos of Britney Spears&apos; new house.&#xA0;\r\n&quot;We didn&apos;t have bad spending habits,&quot; Judy said. &quot;My husband got laid off for a time, and insurance wouldn&apos;t cover Lance&apos;s autism therapy and some other things like his vision and special dental work.&quot;  The couple is now working with a nonprofit group that aids families in crisis to help them negotiate a lower mortgage rate.  &quot;We&apos;re a close family that loves each other,&quot; Judy said. &quot;I feel that I was given this life to show their private visit to London, First Lady Michelle Obama took daughters Sasha and Malia Obama to the West End performance of Disney&apos;s The Lion King on Tuesday.\nThe visit was in celebration of Sasha&apos;s 8th birthday on Wednesday.  \nLook back at all the First Children through the years\nEn route to the United States from Paris, the Obama family has visited the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben, the Harry Potter film set and a traditional British pub, where they enjoyed fish and chips.\n&quot;It was a quiet night - everyone was so surprised,&quot; says waitress Cinthia   Pinto, 24, who served the group on June 8.  &quot;There was no fanfare or hoopla, she tells Usmagazine.com.  &quot;We knew there was a special booking [for a private table of 15], but I had no idea who it would be.&quot;\nSee how the Obamas have spent the first 100 days in office\n&quot;Michelle was holding her daughters&apos; hands [when they came in] and we   escorted them upstairs, where they had the dining room to themselves,&quot; she says. &quot;I have to admit, I was nervous, but Mrs. Obama has a very calm voice,  and she made us feel at ease. She even apologized for causing any trouble. But it was no trouble at all - it was really our honor.&quot;\nAs they sat down and ordered drinks (Pepsi for the girls; house white   wine for Michelle and the other adults), Michelle said to the  waitress, &quot;&apos;I&apos;m looking forward to some famous English food.&apos;&quot;\nCheck out the Obama family photo album\nAfter consulting with the table, Michelle made the order to the   waitress: fish and chips for Malia and Sasha (which consisted   of chunky chips, peas and hand-battered haddock), sirloin Angus   steak and chips for herself and prime beef burgers and chips for the   other men at the table.\n&quot;Everybody was in a good mood and enjoyed their meal,&quot; says Pinto. He is now dating 19-year-old twins Karissa and Kristina Shannon.\r\n&quot;I&apos;m not going to have multiple girlfriends -- not at the same time,&quot; 18-year-old Marston Hefner says in the January issue of Playboy &quot;I can&apos;t imagine that.&quot;\r\nHis brother, 17-year-old Cooper Hefner, begs to differ.\r\n&quot;I can imagine doing that. I don&apos;t think it&apos;s an odd thing to do,&quot; he says. &quot;You date around to try to find a connection with some girl.&quot;\r\nCooper admits he&apos;s &quot;already gotten in trouble&quot; and had the &quot;revolving-door conversation&quot; with his mother, former Playmate Kimberley Conrad.\r\n&quot;One girl comes in the front door while the other one gets pushed out the back,&quot; Cooper says, adding that his mother has told him, &quot;&apos;We do not have a revolving door in this house!&apos; She&apos;s all about one girlfriend at a time,&quot; he says.\r\n\r\nCooper also says growing up in the Playboy mansion is overrated.\r\n&quot;They don&apos;t get it when you say, &apos;There&apos;s nothing to do there,&apos;&quot; he says. &quot;But when you live here and come here every single day, you see the same things. Anybody else would be like, &apos;Let&apos;s go see monkeys!&apos; But I don&apos;t want to see monkeys,&quot; he goes on. &quot;I&apos;d rather go bowling than play with monkeys.&quot;\r\nThough their dad is adored by many, they view him as a bad dancer.\r\n&quot;He is cool out there because his moves are so uncool,&quot; Marston says. &quot;He&apos;s a disco inferno from another planet!&quot;  Adds Cooper, &quot;He&apos;s utterly confused, moving his body -- the fast shuffles, the crazy elbows -- as if he&apos;s not sure what he&apos;s doing. And all these girls on both sides are freaking on him. It should be awkward, but it isn&apos;t for him. It sort of works. Nobody alive can dance like him.&quot;\r\n\r\nSo do the boys ever want to run Playboy one day?\r\n&quot;I definitely want to be involved with the company,&quot; Cooper says. &quot;If I were to take over the company or have a say in what&apos;s going on, I&apos;d want the girls to be presented more as they were in the pictorials back in the 1950s and 1960s -- kind of artsy, classy. I would like to bring back that retro-class feel.&quot;\r\n", "isPartOf": {"@id": Times reports.  \nSee photos of today&apos;s top news stories\nThe news comes one day after federal drug agents and Los Angeles Police Department investigators raided Dr. Conrad Murray&apos;s Houston medical clinic and a public storage unit rented by him.\nAccording to the warrant filed in Harris County District Court, authorities were looking for &quot;items constituting evidence of the offense of manslaughter that tend to show that Dr. Conrad Murray committed the said criminal offense.&quot;\nSee how Michael Jackson&apos;s pill addiction began\nAmong the items seized from the storage unit were two computer hard drives, a Medical Board certificate, letters to a former employee, a list of contacts and papers pertaining to his practice. Among those is a &quot;suspension notice Doctor&apos;s Hospital&quot; and &quot;papers regarding incomplete chart Doctor&apos;s Hospital.&quot;\nAuthorities also seized letters from the Internal Revenue Service, Texas Department of Public Safety controlled substance registration and public records from the Texas controller.\nSee 32 photos from inside Michael Jackson&apos;s Staples Center memorial\nAn administrative assistant at Doctor&apos;s Hospital in Houston said Murray is currently suspended from practicing at the hospital. She said, however, that the offense was &quot;very much&quot; routine and minor and &quot;probably had something to do with a chart that needs to be signed.&quot;\nAn inventory of items taken in the search of Murray&apos;s office included vials of two drugs: 27 tablets of phentermine, a prescription appetite suppressant; and one tablet of clonazepam, a muscle relaxant.\nAuthorities also confiscated a computer, a Rolodex card with Federal Express information and e-mails from one of Murray&apos;s former employees.\nSee how Michael Jackson&apos;s face has changed over the years\nMurray&apos;s attorney, Ed Chernoff, said Wednesday that the doctor would cooperate with investigators.   &quot;We reviewed the warrant and remained on the premises while the search was being executed,&quot; he said.\nMurray, Chernoff added, &quot;was the last doctor standing when Michael Jackson died and it seems all the fury is directed toward him. Dr. Murray is frustrated by negative and often erroneous media reports, he has to walk around 24-7 with a bodyguard. He can&apos;t operate his practice.
